Pl. ed. |publication year=1753;1754 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_100.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria benthamii |accepted_authority=Fenzl ex Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. N. Amer. |place=1: 675. 1840 |year=1840 }} |common_names=Hilly sandwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria benthamii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria benthamii]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 51, 54 |treatment_page=page 52 }}Plants annual. Taproots filiform. Stems 1–40+, erect to ascending, branching, green, 10–30(–50) cm; internodes ± terete, mostly 1–10 times as long as leaves, dull, retrosely puberulent in 2 lines. Leaves usually connate proximally, with scarious sheath 0.2–0.4 mm, petiolate (proximal leaves) or sessile; petiole 2–4 mm; blade 1-veined, vein ± weak abaxially, ovate (petiolate blades) or elliptic-lanceolate to oblanceolate, 5–15(–20) × 2–4 mm, herbaceous, margins undulate, scarious, shiny, sparsely ciliate especially proximally, apex acute to apiculate or cuspidate, often pustulate, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal, open, leafy, 3–50+-flowered cymes. Pedicels erect to reflexed in fruit, 10–40 mm, glabrous. Flowers: sepals green, 1-veined, vein obscure or prominent proximally, not keeled, elliptic to broadly ovate (herbaceous portion light green, ovate), 2–3.5 mm, to 4.5 mm in fruit, apex acute to acuminate, often pustulate, glabrous; petals elliptic, 1.5–3 mm, 1/2–3/4 times as long as sepals, apex obtuse. Capsules loosely to tightly enclosed by calyx, ovoid, 3–4 mm, 11/5–2 times as long as sepals. Seeds 20–30, ashy brown, broadly reniform, compressed, 0.5–0.6 mm, dull, minutely or prominently rounded-tuberculate.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring. |habitat=Open woodlands, limestone slopes and outcrops |elevation=0-400 m |distribution=La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria benthamii |authority=Fenzl ex Torrey & A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring. |habitat=Open woodlands, limestone slopes and outcrops |elevation=0-400 m |distribution=La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León). |reference=None |publication title=Fl. N. Amer. |publication year=1840 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_101.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria benthamii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria humifusa |accepted_authority=Wahlenberg |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Lapp., |place=129. 1812 |year=1812 }} |common_names=Creeping sandwort;sabline rampante |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria humifusa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria humifusa]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 53, 54 |treatment_page=page 52 }}Plants perennial, matted. Tap-roots filiform; rhizomes weak, slender, 0.5–15+ cm. Stems 5–40+, flowering stems erect to ascending, green, 2–8(–10) cm; internodes terete to angular, 1/2–4 times as long as leaves, shiny, glabrous or occasionally sparsely stipitate-glandular at distalmost internodes. Leaves connate basally, with scarious sheath 0.2–0.3 mm, sessile; blade weakly to prominently 1-veined, narrowly oblong or elliptic to ovate-lanceolate, 2–12 × 1–3 mm, subsucculent, margins thickened, herbaceous, shiny, smooth, apex blunt to acute, prominently pustulate or not, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal, open, leafy, 1–3-flowered cymes or often flowers solitary. Pedicels erect in fruit, 1–10 mm, minutely retrorsely pubescent to stipitate-glandular. Flowers: sepals green, 3-veined, 2 lateral veins 1/2–3/4 times as long as midvein, more prominent in fruit, not keeled, ovate (herbaceous portion ovate), 2.5–4 mm, not enlarging in fruit, apex obtuse or somewhat acute, not pustulate, glabrous; petals oblanceolate, 3–4 mm, ± 11/2 times as long as sepals, apex acute. Capsules tightly enclosed by calyx, broadly ellipsoid, 4–4.5 mm, ca. 11/4 times as long as sepals. Seeds 12–18, brown, reniform, compressed, 0.5–0.7 mm, shiny, faintly rugulose. 2n = 40, 44 (both Europe).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Moist, calcareous gravels and rock crevices |elevation=0-100 m |distribution=Greenland;St. Pierre and Miquelon;Man.;Nfld. and Labr.;N.W.T.;N.S.;Nunavut;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Europe. |discussion=

Arenaria humifusa is similar to A. longipedunculata, but is smaller in some dimensions than that species.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria humifusa |authority=Wahlenberg |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Moist, calcareous gravels and rock crevices |elevation=0-100 m |distribution=Greenland;St. Pierre and Miquelon;Man.;Nfld. and Labr.;N.W.T.;N.S.;Nunavut;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Europe. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. Lapp., |publication year=1812 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_102.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria humifusa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

revision.comment: Bot: Adding category [[:Category:Revised Since Print|Revised Since Print]]
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria lanuginosa |accepted_authority=(Michaux) Rohrbach |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in C. F. P. von Martius et al., Fl. Bras. |place=14(2): 274. 1872 |year=1872 }} |common_names=Spreading sandwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Spergulastrum lanuginosum |authority=Michaux |rank=species |publication_title=Fl. Bor.-Amer. |publication_place=1: 275. 1803 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria lanuginosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria lanuginosa]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 52, 54, 55 |treatment_page=page 53 }}Plants ± strongly perennial, possibly blooming first year, not matted. Taproots filiform to moderately thickened; rhizomes often present, slender, 2–15+ cm. Stems 1–80+, erect or ascending to procumbent or prostrate to trailing, green, 5–60 cm; internodes terete to angular, 1/3–8+ times as long as leaves, dull, retrorsely pubescent throughout or in lines, hairs minute. Leaves usually connate basally, with scarious sheath 0.1–0.5 mm, occasionally petiolate (proximal leaves) or sessile; petiole 2–5 mm; blade 1-veined, vein prominent abaxially, linear-lanceolate to narrowly elliptic or oblanceolate, 3–35 × 2–14 mm, herbaceous, margins thickened, scarious, shiny, ciliate proximally or throughout, apex obtuse or acute to apiculate, often minutely pustulate, ciliate on margins and adaxial midrib; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences axillary, solitary flowers or in proliferating, mostly terminal, leafy, 1–80+-flowered cymes. Pedicels erect to ascending (often arcuately so), or straight to widely divergent, often hooked distally in fruit, 2–40 mm, retrorsely pubescent. Flowers: sepals green, 1–3-veined, 2 lateral veins 1/4–3/4 times as long as midvein, often appearing prominently keeled proximally, lanceolate to ovate (herbaceous portion oblong or lanceolate to ovate), 2–5 mm, to 5.5 mm in fruit, apex acute to acuminate, not pustulate, glabrous; petals narrowly spatulate to obovate, 1.5–6 mm, 1/2–12/5 times as long as sepals or absent, apex obtuse to rounded, petals sometimes absent. Capsules ± loosely to tightly enclosed by calyx, ovoid, 3–6 mm, 4/5–11/2 times as long as sepals. Seeds 8–35, black, suborbicular, slightly compressed, 0.7–0.8 mm, shiny, smooth. 2n = 40, 44.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ala.;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;N.C.;N.Mex.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Va.;Central America;South America. |discussion=

Varieties 4+ (2 in the flora).

Arenaria lanuginosa is morphologically diverse, both in our area and southward into northern South America, and is in serious need of comprehensive study. Other species in subg. Leiosperma (e.g., A. gypsostrata B. L. Turner) that occur in Mexico resemble A. lanuginosa; the nature of those relationships also requires study. We have taken the “conservative approach” of treating the two taxa that occur in the flora area as varieties.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stems often 1-10, prostrate to trailing; inflorescences of solitary, axillary flowers; petals absent or 1/ 3/ 4 times as long as sepals |[[Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa|Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stems 1-80+, erect or ascending to procumbent; inflorescences of proliferating, leafy, 1-80+-flowered cymes; petals 3/ 2/ 5 times as long as sepals |[[Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa|Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria lanuginosa |authority=(Michaux) Rohrbach |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Spergulastrum lanuginosum |family=Caryophyllaceae |distribution=Ala.;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;N.C.;N.Mex.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Va.;Central America;South America. |reference=None |publication title=in C. F. P. von Martius et al., Fl. Bras. |publication year=1872 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_103.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria lanuginosa }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Arenaria]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria lanuginosa var. longipedunculata |authority= |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria lanuginosa;Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria lanuginosa]]
variety[[Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 53 }}Stems often 1–10, prostrate to trailing. Inflorescences axillary, solitary flowers. Pedicels straight to widely divergent, often hooked distally in fruit, 25–40 mm. Petals 1/2–3/4 times as long as sepals or absent. 2n = 44 (South America).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Forests, limestone outcrops, moist hummocks, dunes |elevation=0-200 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Mexico;Central America;South America. |discussion=

Variety lanuginosa occurs through much of Mexico, mostly in the mountainous areas. We find material from the southeastern United States to be indistinguishable from many Mexican specimens.

Variety longipedunculata was described from two populations in Georgia and represents plants with particularly long pedicels, 40–50 mm, but this range overlaps that found otherwise in var. lanuginosa.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Arenaria lanuginosa var. longipedunculata |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Forests, limestone outcrops, moist hummocks, dunes |elevation=0-200 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Mexico;Central America;South America. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_104.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria lanuginosa |variety=Arenaria lanuginosa var. lanuginosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria lanuginosa]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) Zarucchi |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sida |place=21: 753. 2004 |year=2004 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Arenaria saxosa |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Smithsonian Contr. Knowl. |publication_place=5(6): 18. 1853 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria confusa |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria lanuginosa subsp. saxosa |authority=(A. Gray) Maguire |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria mearnsii |authority=A. Gray |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria saxosa var. cinerascens |authority=B. L. Robinson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria saxosa var. mearnsii |authority=(Wooton & Standley) Kearney & Peebles |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Sperulastrum lanuginosum subsp. saxosum |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria lanuginosa;Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria lanuginosa]]
variety[[Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 53 }}Stems 1–80+, erect or ascending to procumbent. Inflorescences proliferating, mostly terminal, leafy, 1–80+-flowered cymes. Pedicels erect to ascending (often arcuately so) in fruit, 2–25 mm. Petals 3/4–12/5 times as long as sepals. 2n = 40, 44.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Forests, stream banks |elevation=1000-3100 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico (Baja California;Chihuahua;Coahuila). |discussion=

The varietal combination Arenaria lanuginosa var. cinerascens (B. L. Robinson) Shinners, often applied to this taxon, is not correct because the epithet of the earlier autonym A. saxosa var. saxosa has priority.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa |authority=(A. Gray) Zarucchi |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Arenaria confusa;Arenaria lanuginosa subsp. saxosa;Arenaria mearnsii;Arenaria saxosa var. cinerascens;Arenaria saxosa var. mearnsii;Sperulastrum lanuginosum subsp. saxosum |basionyms=Arenaria saxosa |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Forests, stream banks |elevation=1000-3100 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico (Baja California;Chihuahua;Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Sida |publication year=2004 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_105.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria lanuginosa |variety=Arenaria lanuginosa var. saxosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria lanuginosa]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria livermorensis |accepted_authority=Correll |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=18: 308. 1967 |year=1967 }} |common_names=Livermore sandwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria livermorensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria livermorensis]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 51, 52 |treatment_page=page 54 }}Plants perennial, matted, moss-like. Taproots filiform. Stems 15–25, decumbent, trailing, green, 1–4 cm; internodes angular to grooved, 1–11/2 times as long as leaves, minute, shiny, pubescence of widely spreading to slightly retrorse hairs in 2 lines. Leaves connate basally, with herbaceous sheath 0.1–0.2 mm, sessile; blade 1-veined, vein prominent abaxially, linear, 4–6 × 1 mm, herbaceous, rigid, margins thickened, herbaceous, shiny, lined with peglike cilia, apex acute, pungent-tipped, not pustulate, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters present. Inflorescences solitary flowers in distal leaf axils. Pedicels erect or ascending in fruit, 6–10 mm, minutely pubescent. Flowers: sepals green, 1-veined, slightly keeled proximally, broadly lanceolate (herbaceous portion narrowly lanceolate), 3–4 mm, not enlarging in fruit, apex acute to acuminate, not pustulate, glabrous; petals absent; stamens ca. 8. Capsules very loosely enclosed by calyx, ovoid, 2–3 mm, 2/3–4/5 times as long as sepals. Seeds 5–7, dark brown to black, subglobose, slightly compressed, ca. 1 mm, shiny, smooth.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Crevices of cliffs and bare walls |elevation=2100-2500 m |distribution=Tex. |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Arenaria livermorensis is known only from the Davis Mountains in the Trans-Pecos region of western Texas. It may be related to A. lycopodioides Willdenow ex Schlechtendal, a species found in the mountains of central Mexico.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria livermorensis |authority=Correll |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Crevices of cliffs and bare walls |elevation=2100-2500 m |distribution=Tex. |reference=None |publication title=Brittonia |publication year=1967 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_106.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria livermorensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria longipedunculata |accepted_authority=Hultén |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Not. |place=119: 313, fig. 1. 1966 |year=1966 }} |common_names=Longstem sandwort |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria longipedunculata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria longipedunculata]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 52, 53 |treatment_page=page 54 }}Plants perennial, tufted to mat-forming. Taproots filiform; rhizomes slender, 0.5–3 cm. Stems 25–60+, erect to ascending, green, 2–4 cm; internodes terete, 1–4 times as long as leaves, shiny, minutely glandular-villous. Leaves briefly connate basally, with herbaceous sheath 0.1–0.3 mm, sessile; blade obscurely 1-veined, narrowly elliptic to lanceolate or ovate, 2–6 × 1–1.5 mm, subsucculent, margins thickened, herbaceous, shiny, ciliate proximally, apex acute to apiculate, pustulate, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal, solitary flowers. Pedicels erect in fruit, 10–20 mm, densely glandular-villous. Flowers: sepals green, obscurely veined, not keeled, ovate (herbaceous portion ovate), 3.5–4 mm, not enlarging in fruit, apex acute to acuminate, not pustulate, minutely stipitate-glandular proximally; petals broadly elliptic, 2.5–3.5 mm, 11/4–11/2 times as long as sepals, apex rounded. Capsules tightly enclosed by calyx, ellipsoid, 4–5 mm, 1–11/5 times as long as sepals. Seeds 13–20, brown, reniform, compressed, 0.7–0.9 mm, shiny, rugulose (30×). 2n = 40, 80.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Gravelly, moist, montane areas, open alpine woods |elevation=50-1000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Asia. |discussion=

Arenaria longipedunculata was for many years included in A. humifusa.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria longipedunculata |authority=Hultén |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Gravelly, moist, montane areas, open alpine woods |elevation=50-1000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Asia. |reference=None |publication title=Bot. Not. |publication year=1966 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_107.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria longipedunculata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria ludens |accepted_authority=Shinners |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sida |place=1: 51. 1962 |year=1962 }} |common_names=Trans-Pecos sandwort |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria ludens |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria ludens]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 51 |treatment_page=page 54 }}Plants annual. Taproots filiform. Stems 1–18+, erect to ascending, green or reddish, 15–30(–45) cm; internodes ± terete, 1–10 times as long as leaves, dull, retrorsely pubescent in 2 lines. Leaves usually connate basally, with narrow, scarious sheath 0.2–0.5 mm, petiolate (proximal leaves) or sessile; petiole 2–4 mm; blade 1-veined, vein prominent abaxially, usually narrowly lanceolate, elliptic, or oblanceolate, 10–17 × 2–4 mm, herbaceous, margins ± flat, herbaceous, dull, ciliate in proximal 1/2, apex acute to acuminate, not pustulate, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal, open, minutely bracteate, 3–45+-flowered cymes. Pedicels erect or ascending in fruit, 3–20 mm, retrorsely pubescent in 2 lines. Flowers: sepals green or often purple, 1-veined, strongly keeled proximally, ovate-lanceolate to narrowly lanceolate (herbaceous portion pale, narrowly lanceolate to linear), 3–4 mm, not enlarging in fruit, apex acuminate, not pustulate, glabrous; petals oblong to broadly elliptic, 2.8–4 mm, 1–11/3 times as long as sepals, apex rounded. Capsules loosely enclosed by calyx, ovoid, 3–3.5 mm, 4/5–1 times as long as sepals. Seeds 7–15, dark brown to black, suborbicular, slightly compressed, 0.6–0.7 mm, shiny, obscurely tuberculate (20×).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–early autumn. |habitat=Igneous soil on cliffs and ledges |elevation=1000-2000 m |distribution=Tex.;n Mexico (Coahuila). |discussion=

Arenaria ludens may be more closely related to A. lanuginosa than to A. benthamii, the taxon with which it is often confused, if seed morphology is any indication.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria ludens |authority=Shinners |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering late summer–early autumn. |habitat=Igneous soil on cliffs and ledges |elevation=1000-2000 m |distribution=Tex.;n Mexico (Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Sida |publication year=1962 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_108.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria ludens }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria paludicola |accepted_authority=B. L. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=29: 298. 1894 |year=1894 }} |common_names=Marsh sandwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Alsine palustris |authority=Kellogg |rank=species |publication_title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci. |publication_place=3: 61. 1863 (as palustre), }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Minuartia paludicola |authority=(B. L. Robinson) House |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria paludicola |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria paludicola]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 52, 126 |treatment_page=page 55 }}Plants perennial, not matted. Taproots filiform; rhizomes slender, 15+ cm. Stems 5–15, weakly erect, green, 25–90 cm; internodes angular to grooved, 2/3–3 times as long as leaves, shiny, glabrous except for fine hairs at nodes. Leaves connate basally, with scarious sheath 0.2–0.5 mm, sessile; blade 1-veined (vein prominent abaxially), linear to linear-lanceolate, 20–55 × 2–7 mm, herbaceous to subsucculent, margins ± flat, scarious, shiny, ciliate, apex acute or acuminate to cuspidate, sometimes pustulate, sparsely pubescent on adaxial surface; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences axillary, solitary flowers. Pedicels reflexed in fruit, 20–50 mm, glabrous. Flowers: sepals green, obscurely 1-veined, not keeled, broadly elliptic (herbaceous portion narrowly elliptic), 2.8–3.5 mm, to ca. 4 mm in fruit, apex obtuse to rounded, not pustulate, minutely ciliate basally; petals ovate, 5–6 mm, 11/2–2 times as long as sepals, apex rounded. Capsules tightly enclosed by calyx, ovoid, 4 mm, ca. equaling sepals. Seeds 15–20, dark brown, reniform, compressed, 0.8–0.9 mm, shiny, smooth.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–summer. |habitat=Boggy meadows, freshwater marshes |elevation=0-300 m |distribution=Calif.;c Mexico;Central America (Guatemala). |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Arenaria paludicola is federally listed as endangered, and now is known only from a few sites in San Luis Obispo County; urban development and resultant habitat conversion have impacted it significantly. Historical collections of A. paludicola are known from other areas of the California coast and from Washington.

Arenaria paludicola occurs also in Mexico, where it grows (and is sometimes confused) with A. bourgaei Hemsley in lakes and wet areas above 2000 meters; the relationship of these species to each other and to A. lanuginosa requires study.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria paludicola |authority=B. L. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Minuartia paludicola |basionyms=Alsine palustris |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–summer. |habitat=Boggy meadows, freshwater marshes |elevation=0-300 m |distribution=Calif.;c Mexico;Central America (Guatemala). |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria paludicola }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria pseudofrigida |accepted_authority=(Ostenfeld & Dahl) Schischkin & Knorring |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in V. L. Komarov et al., Fl. URSS |place=6: 537. 1936 |year=1936 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Arenaria ciliata subsp. pseudofrigida |authority=Ostenfeld & Dahl |rank=subspecies |publication_title=Nyt Mag. Naturvidensk. |publication_place=55: 217. 1918 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Arenaria ciliata var. pseudofrigida |authority=(Ostenfeld & Dahl) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria pseudofrigida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria pseudofrigida]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 52 |treatment_page=page 55 }}Plants perennial, forming cushions or mats. Taproots filiform to somewhat thickened. Stems 20–40+, procumbent, green, 3–14 cm; internodes terete to angular, 1/2–1+ times as long as leaves, shiny, pubescent in lines or throughout, hairs retrorsely curved. Leaves connate basally, with scarious sheath 0.2–0.3 mm, sessile; blade 1-veined (prominent proximally), oblanceolate to spatulate, 2–6 × 0.8–1.8 mm, succulent, margins thickened, minutely scarious-granular, ± shiny, ciliate in proximal 1/2, apex ± obtuse, sometimes pustulate, glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal or axillary, open, leafy, 1–4-flowered cymes in distal leaf axils. Pedicels erect or nodding in fruit, 2–12 mm, retrorsely pubescent. Flowers: sepals green or distally purple, 3-veined (2 lateral veins 1/2 times as long as midvein), sometimes keeled, narrowly lanceolate (herbaceous portion narrowly lanceolate), 3–4 mm, to ca. 5 mm in fruit, apex ± acute, not pustulate, glabrous or sparsely stipitate-glandular; petals obovate, 5–8 mm, 12/3–2 times as long as sepals, apex acute to rounded. Capsules tightly enclosed by calyx, narrowly ellipsoid to cylindric, 3–5 mm, ca. equaling sepals. Seeds 15–20, black to reddish brown, reniform, compressed, 0.8–0.9 mm, shiny, low-tuberculate. 2n = 40.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Open, dry to slightly moist sand or gravel |elevation=0-50 m |distribution=Greenland;Europe. |discussion=

We follow B. Jonsell (2001) in treating Arenaria pseudofrigida as one of several arctic species that formerly were included in A. ciliata Linnaeus, a species now considered restricted to alpine regions of central Europe.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arenaria pseudofrigida |authority=(Ostenfeld & Dahl) Schischkin & Knorring |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Arenaria ciliata var. pseudofrigida |basionyms=Arenaria ciliata subsp. pseudofrigida |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Open, dry to slightly moist sand or gravel |elevation=0-50 m |distribution=Greenland;Europe. |reference=None |publication title=in V. L. Komarov et al., Fl. Alsinoideae |genus=Arenaria |species=Arenaria pseudofrigida }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arenaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Arenaria serpyllifolia |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 423. 1753 |year=1753 }} |common_names=Thymeleaf sandwort;sabline á feuilles de serpolet |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=W |label=Weedy }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae;Arenaria;Arenaria serpyllifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Alsinoideae]]
genus[[Arenaria]]
species[[Arenaria serpyllifolia]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 51, 56 |treatment_page=page 55 }}Plants annual. Taproots filiform. Stems 1–100+, erect to ascending or sprawling, green, 3–40+ cm; internodes terete to ellipsoid, 2–8 times as long as leaves, dull, retrorsely pubescent throughout, sometimes also stipitate-glandular. Leaves often connate basally, with scarious or mostly herbaceous sheath 0.2–0.3 mm, petiolate (proximal leaves) or usually sessile; petiole 1–4 mm; blade 3–5 veined, elliptic to broadly ovate or rarely orbiculate, 2–7 × 1–4 mm, herbaceous, margins flat, herbaceous, dull, ciliate especially proximally, apex acute to acuminate, pustulate, sparsely minutely pubescent or glabrous; axillary leaf clusters absent. Inflorescences terminal, open, leafy, 3–50+-flowered cymes. Pedicels erect or ascending in fruit, 1–12 mm, retrorsely pubescent. Flowers: sepals green, often prominently 3-veined, not keeled, lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate (herbaceous portion narrowly elliptic to broadly lanceolate), 2–3 mm, to 4 mm in fruit, apex narrowly acute to acuminate, ± minutely pustulate, stipitate-glandular; petals oblong, 0.6–2.7 mm, 1/5–3/4 times as long as sepals, apex obtuse to rounded. Capsules loosely enclosed by calyx, ovoid to cylindric-ovoid, 3–3.5 mm, 4/5–11/5 times as long as sepals. Seeds 10–15, ashy black, reniform, plump, 0.4–0.6 mm, not shiny, with low-elongate, prominent tubercules.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;D.C.;Del.;Fla.;Ga.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Mont.;N.C.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Nev.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;North America;Eurasia;Africa;introduced in Australia. |introduced=true |discussion=

Varieties 3+ (2 in the flora).

Variation in Arenaria serpyllifolia in the broad sense is treated in various ways. The two varieties recognized here have been treated also as subspecies (e.g., A. O. Chater and G. Halliday 1993) or species (e.g., M. N. Abuhadra 2000; B. Jonsell 2001). Jonsell admitted that accepting them as species is questionable; while the morphological differences are slight (see esp. Abuhadra), the ploidy-level difference (2n = 40 in var. serpyllifolia vs. 2n = 20 in var. tenuior) is important.

|tables= |references= }}

|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 56 }}Sepals 2–3 mm, not enlarging in fruit. Capsules cylindric to cylindric-ovoid, not significantly broader at base (walls nearly straight). Seeds ca. 0.4 mm. 2n = 20 (Europe).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Roadsides, open, sandy or rocky, disturbed sites |elevation=0-400 m |distribution=Ark.;D.C.;Fla.;Ga.;Ky.;La.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;Pa.;S.C.;Tenn.;Va.;Europe;w Asia;n Africa;introduced in Australia. |introduced=true |discussion=

Variety tenuior is to be expected elsewhere.

Pl. ed. |place=5, 407. 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Arethusa;dragon’s-mouth;aréthuse |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orchidaceae;Orchidaceae subfam. tribe[[Orchidaceae tribe Arethuseae]]
subtribe[[Orchidaceae (tribe Arethuseae) subtribe Arethusinae]]
genus[[Arethusa]]
|etymology=Greek Arethusa, mythical river nymph |volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 497, 598 |treatment_page=page 596 }}Herbs, perennial. Roots few, slender, fleshy. Stems scapose, at base a bulbous corm. Leaves solitary, basal; blade subtended by 2–3 tubular sheaths, obscurely plicate, linear-lanceolate, developing during and after anthesis. Inflorescences terminal; floral bracts minute. Flowers solitary (rarely 2), resupinate, erect, showy; anther with pair of soft yellow-green pollinia; stigma emergent, with free lateral lobes. Fruits capsules, erect.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America. |discussion=

Species 1.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Arethusa |author=Charles J. Sheviak;Paul M. Catling |authority=Linnaeus |rank=genus |parent rank=subtribe |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orchidaceae |distribution=North America. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl.;Gen. |volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 594 |treatment_page=page 597 }}Plants 2–40 cm. Leaves: blade 5–23 cm × 3–12 mm. Inflorescences: floral bracts 2, inconspicuous. Flowers pink to magenta, rarely white or bluish, gaping, large; sepals erect, narrowly oblanceolate to narrowly oblong, 20–55 × 3–9 mm; petals arcuate, 23–49 × 4–10 mm; lip obovate to oblong, arcuate to reflexed near middle, often obscurely 3-lobed, 19–35 ×10–19 mm; disc with crest of yellow lamellae and fleshy processes. Capsules erect, ovoid to ellipsoid, 15–25 mm. 2n = 40.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul. |habitat=Sphagnum bogs, coniferous swamps, calcareous treed to open fens, and moist, acid, sandy meadows |elevation=0–1100 m |distribution=Man.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Conn.;Del.;Ind.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;Tenn.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

The occurrence of Arethusa bulbosa in Cook County, Illinois (F. Swink and G. S. Wilhelm 1994), and in Maryland are unconfirmed.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 508. 175 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Pl. ed. |place=5, 225. 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Prickly-poppy |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
|etymology=a poppylike herb mentioned by Pliny |volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs or subshrubs, annual or perennial, caulescent, glaucous, from transitory or persistent taproots; sap white to orange. Stems leafy, branching. Leaves sessile; basal rosulate, cauline alternate; blade unlobed or commonly shallowly to deeply 1×-lobed; margins dentate, each tooth terminated by prickle; surfaces glaucous, often mottled over veins, unarmed or prickly, glabrous or hispid. Inflorescences terminal, cymose; bracts present. Flowers conspicuous, sometimes subtended by foliaceous bracts; sepals 2 or 3, unarmed or prickly, each with erect, subterminal, hollow horn tipped with prickle; petals 6, in 2 whorls of 3; stamens 20-250 or more; pistil 3-5(-7)-carpellate; ovary 1-locular; style short, to 3 mm in fruit; stigma 3-5(-7)-lobed. Capsules erect, 3-5(-7)-valved, grooved over sutures, prickly, rarely unarmed, dehiscing from apex ca. 1/3 length, valves separating from framework of vascular elements, to which persistent style and stigma remain attached. Seeds numerous, subglobose, minutely pitted, 1-3 mm, aril present. x = 14.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;South America;Hawaii;introduced in other tropical and temperate regions of the world. |discussion=

Species 32 (15 in the flora).

None of the North American species occurs in South America except for the pantropical weeds Argemone mexicana and, probably, A. ochroleuca. Argemone glauca is endemic to Hawaii. Three suffrutescent, perennial species are known from Mexico in Coahuila (A. fruticosa) and Chihuahua (A. turnerae, A. ownbeyana).

Most herbaceous species can be hybridized, but the F1 plants are sterile when the parents differ in ploidy level. The F2 generation, when achieved, consists mainly of plants of low vigor.

The alkaloids of Argemone have been studied extensively. F. S. Stermitz (1968) has suggested that the species fall into four groups (one with two subgroups) according to their alkaloidal properties, and that these groups coincide to a considerable degree with the informal species alliances suggested by G. B. Ownbey (1958). A full evaluation of the importance of alkaloidal content to Argemone taxonomy and evolution has not been published, but there is little doubt that it is highly significant.

The name Argemone intermedia Sweet (Hort. Brit. ed. 2, 1830) is encountered in several regional and local floras but is of uncertain application.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=ownbey1958a |text=Ownbey, G. B. 1958. Monograph of the genus Argemone for North America and the West Indies. Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 1-159. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=ownbey1961a |text=Ownbey, G. B. 1961. The genus Argemone in South America and Hawaii. Brittonia 13: 91-109. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=prain1895a |text=Prain, D. 1895. An account of the genus Argemone. J. Bot. 33: 129-135, 176-178, 207-209, 307-312, 325-333, 363-371. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=stermitz1969a |text=Stermitz, F. R., D. E. Nicodem, Wei C. C., and K. D. McMurtrey. 1969. Alkaloids of Argemone polyanthemos, A. corymbosa, A. chisosensis, A. sanguinea, A. aurantiaca and general Argemone systematics. Phytochemistry 8: 615-620. }} }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone aenea |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 50. 1958 |year=1958 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone aenea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone aenea]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or short-lived perennial. Stems 3-8 dm, prickly. Leaf blades: abaxial surface prickly on veins, adaxial surface unarmed or sparingly prickly on veins; proximal lobed 3/4-5/6 distance to midrib. Inflorescences: buds ellipsoid-oblong, body 15-20 × 13-16 mm, prickly; sepal horns terete, 7-12 mm, unarmed or with a few basal prickles. Flowers 7-12 cm broad, often subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals bright yellow to golden or bronze; stamens ca. 150; filaments red or purplish; pistil 4-5-carpellate. Capsules narrowly ellipsoid-oblong, 25-35 × 12-16 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), coarsely prickly, surface clearly visible, prickles very unequal, longest ca. 8 mm. Seeds 1.5-1.7 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting early spring–summer. |habitat=Dry plains and low hills, road and field margins |elevation=0-1500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León;and Tamaulipas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone aenea |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting early spring–summer. |habitat=Dry plains and low hills, road and field margins |elevation=0-1500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León;and Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1149.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone aenea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone albiflora |accepted_authority=Hornemann |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Hort. Bot. Hafn. |place=2: 489. 1815 |year=1815 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=W2 |label= }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone albiflora |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone albiflora]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or biennial. Stems 4-10(-15) dm, sparingly to moderately prickly. Leaf blades: abaxial surface sparingly prickly on main veins, adaxial surface unarmed or sparingly prickly on main veins; basal and proximal lobed 1/2-4/5 distance to midrib; distal clasping. Inflorescences: buds broadly ellipsoid to subglobose, body 12-18 × 10-16 mm, sparingly to rather closely prickly; sepal horns terete, 3-6(-10) mm, usually unarmed. Flowers 5-10 cm broad, closely to more distantly subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals white; stamens 150 or more; filaments lemon yellow; pistil (3-)4-5(-7)-carpellate. Capsules oblong, oblong-ellipsoid, or narrowly ellipsoid, 20-40(-45) × 10-15(-25) mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), prickly, surface clearly visible to partially obscured, longest prickles widely spaced, 6-10(-12) mm, sometimes interspersed with smaller ones. Seeds 1.6-2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;La.;Mass.;Mich.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;N.Y.;S.C.;Tex. |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone albiflora subsp. albiflora |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone albiflora;Argemone albiflora subsp. albiflora |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone albiflora]]
subspecies[[Argemone albiflora subsp. albiflora]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems sparsely prickly. Leaf blades: basal and proximal lobed 1/2-2/3 distance to midrib. Inflorescences: sepal horns 3-5 mm, unarmed. Capsules oblong to oblong-ellipsoid, surface clearly visible, prickles widely spaced, equal, 6-8(-10) mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early spring–summer; fruiting late spring–summer. |habitat=Waste places, roadsides, fields, beaches, dunes, coastal plains |elevation=0-300 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;La.;Mass.;Mich.;Miss.;Mo.;N.Y.;N.C.;S.C. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone albiflora subsp. albiflora |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering early spring–summer; fruiting late spring–summer. |habitat=Waste places, roadsides, fields, beaches, dunes, coastal plains |elevation=0-300 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;La.;Mass.;Mich.;Miss.;Mo.;N.Y.;N.C.;S.C. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_984.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone albiflora |subspecies=Argemone albiflora subsp. albiflora }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone albiflora]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone albiflora subsp. texana |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 141. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone albiflora var. texana |authority=(G. B. Ownbey) Shinners |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone albiflora;Argemone albiflora subsp. texana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone albiflora]]
subspecies[[Argemone albiflora subsp. texana]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems sparsely to moderately prickly. Leaf blades: basal and proximal lobed nearly to midrib. Inflorescences: sepal horns 4-6(-10) mm, unarmed or sparingly prickly near base. Capsules usually narrowly ellipsoid, surface partially obscured, longer prickles widely spaced, interspersed with numerous, shorter, unequal ones. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early spring–summer; fruiting spring–fall. |habitat=Pastures and waste ground |elevation=0-300 m |distribution=Ark.;La.;Mo.;Tex. |discussion=

Argemone albiflora subsp. texana is introduced in Arkansas and Missouri.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone albiflora subsp. texana |authority=G. B. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone arizonica |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 91. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone arizonica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone arizonica]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants perennial. Stems 5-8 dm, diffusely branched, often decumbent, copiously long-prickly. Leaf blades: surfaces sparingly long-prickly on veins; basal and proximal lobed nearly to midrib, lobe length often to 5 times width; distal not clasping. Inflorescences: buds ellipsoid-oblong, body 15-18 × 12-15 mm, prickly; sepal horns slender, terete, 12-15 mm, prickly at base. Flowers 7-10 cm broad; petals white; stamens 100 or more; filaments pale yellow; pistil 3-carpellate. Capsules narrowly ellipsoid-oblong, 35-45 × 10-14 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), closely prickly, longest prickles 8-10 mm. Seeds ca. 2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting summer. |habitat=Precipitous slopes |elevation=1000-2000 m |distribution=Ariz. |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Argemone arizonica grows well in Grand Canyon National Park, especially along the Kaibab and Bright Angel trails.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone arizonica |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting summer. |habitat=Precipitous slopes |elevation=1000-2000 m |distribution=Ariz. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status=Conservation concern;Endemic;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1017.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone arizonica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone aurantiaca |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 53. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone aurantiaca |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone aurantiaca]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or biennial. Stems widely branching, to ca. 8 dm, prickly throughout. Leaf blades: abaxial surface sparingly to copiously prickly on and sometimes between veins, adaxial surface less so; proximal lobed 5/6 distance to midrib; distal often clasping. Inflorescences: buds oblong, body 18-25 × 14-18 mm, prickly, longest prickles sometimes branched; sepal horns angular in cross section or flattened, 8-12 mm, prickly, apical prickle indurate. Flowers 8-12 cm broad, closely subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals white; stamens 150 or more; filaments pale yellow; pistil 5-6-carpellate. Capsules ovoid, 40-50 × 15-25 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles); prickles herbaceous, erect or reflexed, often branched, very unequal, longest 15-35 mm. Seeds 2.5-3 mm. 2n = 84.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Fields, pastures, hills |elevation=150-500 m (transition zone between lowlands and plateau) |distribution=Tex. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone aurantiaca |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Fields, pastures, hills |elevation=150-500 m (transition zone between lowlands and plateau) |distribution=Tex. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_588.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone aurantiaca }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone chisosensis |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 114. 1958 |year=1958 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone chisosensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone chisosensis]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants biennial or perennial. Stems 4-8 dm, sparingly to copiously prickly, prickles long, patent. Leaf blades: abaxial surface prickly on main veins, adaxial surface less prickly to almost unarmed on veins. Inflorescences: buds broadly ellipsoid, body 15-20 × 11-15 mm, prickly, prickles patent; sepal horns terete or angular in cross section, 7-12 mm, basally prickly. Flowers 7-10 cm broad, usually closely subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals white or pale lavender; stamens 150 or more; filaments pale lemon yellow or red; pistil 3-4-carpellate. Capsules narrowly ellipsoid-lanceoloid to ellipsoid-ovoid, 30-45 × 8-13 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), prickly, surface clearly visible; longest prickles scattered, to 10 mm, interspersed with a few shorter ones. Seeds 1.8-2.2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall. |habitat=Arid plains and mountains |elevation=900-2000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua and Coahuila). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone chisosensis |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall. |habitat=Arid plains and mountains |elevation=900-2000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua and Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1145.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone chisosensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone corymbosa |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Calif. Acad. Sci. |place=2: 59. 1886 |year=1886 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone intermedia var. corymbosa |authority=(Greene) Eastwood |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone corymbosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone corymbosa]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants perennial. Stems 2-8 dm, scattered-prickly. Leaf blades: surfaces shallowly to deeply lobed, thick, leathery, surfaces unarmed to sparingly prickly, especially abaxial surface on veins; distal clasping. Inflorescences: buds subglobose to ellipsoid-ovoid, body 10-18 × 8-14 mm, sparingly prickly; sepal horns terete or flattened in cross section, 5-7 mm. Flowers 4-9 cm broad; petals white; stamens 100-120; filaments pale yellow; pistil 3-5-carpellate. Capsules ovoid to lanceoloid, 25-35 × 10-16 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), prickly, surface clearly visible, prickles simple, well spaced, subequal, longest 5-7 mm. Seeds 1.5-2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Utah |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaf blades essentially unlobed to lobed ca. 1/4 distance to midrib. |[[Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa|Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaf blades lobed 1/2–3/4 distance to midrib. |[[Argemone corymbosa subsp. arenicola|Argemone corymbosa subsp. arenicola]] |}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone corymbosa;Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone corymbosa]]
subspecies[[Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Leaf blades essentially unlobed to lobed ca. 1/4 distance to midrib.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring. |habitat=Dry flats and slopes, stabilized dunes, washes, sandy or granitic soil |elevation=400-900 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif. |discussion=

Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa grows in the Mojave Desert-Panamint Valley area.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring. |habitat=Dry flats and slopes, stabilized dunes, washes, sandy or granitic soil |elevation=400-900 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1060.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone corymbosa |subspecies=Argemone corymbosa subsp. corymbosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone corymbosa]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone gracilenta |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 346. 1898 |year=1898 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone gracilenta |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone gracilenta]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants perennial. Stems 4-12(-18) dm, moderately prickly throughout, prickles patent, longest 7-10 mm. Leaf blades: abaxial surface prickly on main veins, adaxial surface unarmed or sparingly prickly on midrib; basal blades shallowly to often deeply lobed; distal not clasping. Inflorescences: buds subglobose to oblong, body 15-18 × 12-15 mm, sparingly prickly, prickles patent; sepal horns usually slender, terete, (5-)8-12(-14) mm, unarmed or with 1-2 prickles near base. Flowers 6-9 cm broad; petals white; stamens about 150; filaments pale yellow; pistil 3-4-carpellate. Capsules narrowly ellipsoid to narrowly ellipsoid-ovoid, 30-45 × 8-14 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), scattered-prickly, surface clearly visible, longest prickles 6-8(-10) mm. Seeds to 2 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting spring–summer. |habitat=Washes and outwash plains, deserts |elevation=0-900 m (s to n) |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico (Sonora and Baja California). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone gracilenta |authority=Greene |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting spring–summer. |habitat=Washes and outwash plains, deserts |elevation=0-900 m (s to n) |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico (Sonora and Baja California). |reference=None |publication title=Pittonia |publication year=1898 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_674.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone gracilenta }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone hispida |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=4: 5. 1849 |year=1849 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone bipinnatifida |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone platyceras var. hispida |authority=(A. Gray) Prain |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone hispida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone hispida]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants perennial. Stems 3-6 dm, densely prickly and crisped-hispid. Leaf blades: surfaces sparsely to densely crisped-hispid between veins, abaxial surface mostly densely prickly on midrib and main veins, adaxial surface less so; proximal lobed 4/5 distance to midrib; distal not clasping. Inflorescences: buds oblong, body 16-20 × 14-18 mm, prickly and hispid; sepal horns 4-7 mm, prickly, apical prickle flattened, indurate. Flowers 7-10 cm broad; petals white; stamens 150 or more; filaments pale yellow; pistil 3-4-carpellate. Capsules ovoid, 30-40 × 12-18 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), densely prickly, surface obscured, longest prickles straight or incurved, ca. 5 mm. Seeds ca. 2.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Prairies, slopes, and eastern foothills of the Laramie and Rocky mountains |elevation=1400-2100 m |distribution=Colo.;N.Mex.;Wyo. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone hispida |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Argemone bipinnatifida;Argemone platyceras var. hispida |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Prairies, slopes, and eastern foothills of the Laramie and Rocky mountains |elevation=1400-2100 m |distribution=Colo.;N.Mex.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication year=1849 |special status=Endemic;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1068.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone hispida }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone mexicana |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 508. 1753 |year=1753 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=W2 |label= }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone leiocarpa |authority=Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone mexicana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone mexicana]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual. Stems often branching from base, 2.5-8 dm, unarmed or sparingly prickly. Leaf blades: surfaces unarmed or sparingly prickly on veins; proximal lobed 1/2 or more distance to midrib; distal more shallowly lobed, mostly clasping. Inflorescences: buds subglobose, body 10-15 × 9-13 mm, unarmed or sparingly prickly; sepal horns terete, 5-10 mm, unarmed. Flowers 4-7 cm broad, subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals bright yellow or rarely pale lemon yellow; stamens 30-50; filaments yellow; pistil 4-6-carpellate. Capsules oblong to broadly ellipsoid, 25-45 × 12-20 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles when present), unarmed or prickly, longest prickles 6-10 mm. Seeds 1.6-2 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall, or throughout year in tropics. |habitat=Waste places, often a weed of roadsides, dooryards, fallow fields |elevation=0-1500 m |distribution=Ont.;Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Kans.;La.;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Pa.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America. |discussion=

Argemone mexicana is probably native to southern Florida as well as the Caribbean islands and has been introduced along the coast of the United States from New England to Texas and, more infrequently, inland. Although it has been reported from Mississippi, no specimens are known. It is widespread in temperate and tropical regions around the world by introduction.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone mexicana |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Argemone leiocarpa |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall, or throughout year in tropics. |habitat=Waste places, often a weed of roadsides, dooryards, fallow fields |elevation=0-1500 m |distribution=Ont.;Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Kans.;La.;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Pa.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1753 |special status=W2;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_201.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone mexicana }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone munita |accepted_authority=Durand & Hilgard |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=J. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia, ser. |place=2, 3: 37. 1854 |year=1854 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone munita |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone munita]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or perennial. Stems 4-16 dm, densely to sparingly prickly. Leaf blades: surfaces copiously prickly on veins and intervein surfaces to sparingly prickly on main veins only; basal lobed ca. 1/2 distance to midrib, lobe apices usually distinctly rounded, marginal teeth usually less than 1 mm; distal usually definitely clasping. Inflorescences: buds oblong to ellipsoid to obovoid, body 12-22 × 10-16 mm, prickly; sepal horns terete, flattened or angular in cross section, (4-)6-8(-10) mm, unarmed to densely prickly. Flowers 5-10(-13) cm broad, not closely subtended by foliaceous bracts; petals white; stamens 150-250; filaments pale yellow; pistil 3-5-carpellate. Capsules ovoid, ellipsoid, or lanceoloid, 35-55 × 9-15(-18) mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), prickly, longest prickles to 10 mm, widely spaced, or shorter, more numerous, and interspersed with still shorter prickles, surface then partially obscured. Seeds 1.8-2.6 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah |discussion=

Subspecies 4 (4 in the flora).

The Kawaiisu used Argemone munita medicinally to treat burns (D. E. Moerman 1986, no varieties specified).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Prickles 0–30 per cm² on main stem below capsule; leaf surfaces unarmed or sparingly prickly on veins and intervein areas. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Prickles 100–500 per cm² on main stem below capsule; leaf surfaces mostly closely prickly on veins and intervein areas. |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Prickles 0–10 per cm²; abaxial leaf surface sparingly prickly on main veins, adaxial surface usually unarmed. |[[Argemone munita subsp. robusta|Argemone munita subsp. robusta]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Prickles 10–30 per cm²; both leaf surfaces sparingly to moderately prickly on veins and often on intervein areas. |[[Argemone munita subsp. munita|Argemone munita subsp. munita]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Longest prickles of stem 4–6 mm; stems usually purplish; bud prickles sometimes branched. |[[Argemone munita subsp. rotundata|Argemone munita subsp. rotundata]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Longest prickles of stem 7–10 mm; stems greenish white; bud prickles simple. |[[Argemone munita subsp. argentea|Argemone munita subsp. argentea]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Argemone munita |authority=Durand & Hilgard |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah |reference=None |publication title=J. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia, ser. |publication year=1854 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_102.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone munita }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Argemone]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone munita subsp. argentea |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 83. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone munita var. argentea |authority=(G. B. Ownbey) Shinners |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone munita;Argemone munita subsp. argentea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone munita]]
subspecies[[Argemone munita subsp. argentea]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems greenish white, 4-8 dm, with 100-300 prickles per cm⊃2; on main stem below capsule, longest prickles 7-10 mm. Leaf blades: surfaces usually densely prickly on veins and intervein areas. Inflorescences: bud prickles simple. Capsules densely prickly, surface partially obscured, prickles unequal, longest 7-10 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting spring–summer. |habitat=Dry desert ranges |elevation=150-850 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Nev. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone munita subsp. argentea |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Argemone munita var. argentea |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring; fruiting spring–summer. |habitat=Dry desert ranges |elevation=150-850 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Nev. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_602.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone munita |subspecies=Argemone munita subsp. argentea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone munita]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone munita subsp. munita |accepted_authority=Durand & Hilgard |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone munita;Argemone munita subsp. munita |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone munita]]
subspecies[[Argemone munita subsp. munita]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 6-15 dm, with 10-30 prickles per cm⊃2; on main stem below capsule. Leaf blades: surfaces sparingly to moderately prickly on veins and intervein areas. Capsules moderately prickly, surface not obscured, prickles uneven, longest 5-8 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Dry foothills and slopes |elevation=100-1500 m |distribution=Calif.;Mexico (Baja California). |discussion=

Argemone munita subsp. munita grows in the Coast Ranges. Intermediates between it and subsp. rotundata are frequent.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone munita subsp. munita |authority=Durand & Hilgard |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Dry foothills and slopes |elevation=100-1500 m |distribution=Calif.;Mexico (Baja California). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_490.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone munita |subspecies=Argemone munita subsp. munita }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone munita]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone munita subsp. robusta |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 77. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone munita var. robusta |authority=(G. B. Ownbey) Shinners |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone munita;Argemone munita subsp. robusta |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone munita]]
subspecies[[Argemone munita subsp. robusta]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 5-16 dm, with 0-10 prickles per cm⊃2; on main stem below capsule. Leaf blades: abaxial surface sparingly prickly on main veins. Capsules scattered-prickly, surface not obscured, prickles nearly equal, longest 6-8 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Dry, rocky soil, full sun |elevation=1500-1700 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Argemone munita subsp. robusta is endemic to the Santa Ana Mountains.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone munita subsp. robusta |authority=G. B. Ownbey |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Argemone munita var. robusta |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Dry, rocky soil, full sun |elevation=1500-1700 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_691.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone munita |subspecies=Argemone munita subsp. robusta }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone munita]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone munita subsp. rotundata |accepted_authority=(Rydberg) G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=21: 77. 1958 |year=1958 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Argemone rotundata |authority=Rydberg |rank=species |publication_title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication_place=29: 160. 1902 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone munita var. rotundata |authority=(Rydberg) Shinners |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone munita;Argemone munita subsp. rotundata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone munita]]
subspecies[[Argemone munita subsp. rotundata]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems usually purplish, 4-10 dm, with 120-500 prickles per cm⊃2; on main stem below capsule, longest prickles 4-6 mm. Leaf blades: surfaces usually densely prickly on veins and intervein areas. Inflorescences: bud prickles sometimes branched. Capsules usually densely prickly, surface partially obscured, prickles unequal, longest to 8 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Open slopes and foothills, full sun |elevation=1200-2500 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone munita subsp. rotundata |authority=(Rydberg) G. B. Ownbey |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Argemone munita var. rotundata |basionyms=Argemone rotundata |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Open slopes and foothills, full sun |elevation=1200-2500 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah. |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1958 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_598.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone munita |subspecies=Argemone munita subsp. rotundata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone munita]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone ochroleuca |accepted_authority=Sweet |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brit. Fl. Gard. |place=3: plate 242. 1828 |year=1828 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Argemone mexicana var. ochroleuca |authority=(Sweet) Lindley |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone ochroleuca |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone ochroleuca]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or short-lived perennial. Stems branching distally, 3-10 dm, sparingly prickly. Leaf blades: abaxial surface sparingly prickly on veins, adaxial surface usually unarmed; proximal deeply lobed nearly to midrib; distal more shallowly lobed, usually clasping. Inflorescences: buds oblong, body 8-18 × 4-11 mm, with 4-10 prickles per sepal; sepal horns terete, 5-12 mm, unarmed. Flowers 3-7 cm broad, closely subtended by 1-2 foliaceous bracts; petals lemon yellow or rarely darker yellow; stamens 20-75; filaments yellow; pistil 3-6-carpellate. Capsules ovoid-ellipsoid to oblong, 20-50 × 10-18 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), longest prickles 8-12 mm. Seeds 1.5-2 mm. 2n = 56.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall. |habitat=Disturbed soil, often a weed of fields, roadways, embankments, intermountain plains |elevation=0-2250 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |introduced=true |discussion=

Argemone ochroleuca is widespread in temperate and tropical regions of the world as an introduced weed.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone ochroleuca |authority=Sweet |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Argemone mexicana var. ochroleuca |basionyms= |family=Papaveraceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting spring–fall. |habitat=Disturbed soil, often a weed of fields, roadways, embankments, intermountain plains |elevation=0-2250 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Brit. Fl. Gard. |publication year=1828 |special status=Illustrated;Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_206.xml |genus=Argemone |species=Argemone ochroleuca }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Argemone]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone pleiacantha |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Feddes Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. |place=6: 161. 1908 |year=1908 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Papaveraceae;Argemone;Argemone pleiacantha |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Papaveraceae]]
genus[[Argemone]]
species[[Argemone pleiacantha]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Plants annual or perennial. Stems branched, 5-12 dm, sparingly to closely prickly. Leaf blades: abaxial surface sparingly prickly on veins, adaxial surface unarmed or sparingly prickly on veins, apices of lobes angular, marginal teeth prominent; proximal lobed ca. 3/4 distance to midrib; distal sometimes clasping. Inflorescences: buds oblong-obovoid or subglobose, body 14-20 × 11-18 mm, prickly, prickles simple or branched; sepal horns terete or adaxially flattened, 4-12 mm. Flowers 8-12(-16) cm broad; petals white; stamens ca. 150; filaments pale yellow to red; pistil 3-4-carpellate. Capsules ovoid to ellipsoid-lanceoloid, 25-45 × 10-16 mm (including stigma and excluding prickles), closely to sparingly prickly, longest prickles 4-6(-8) mm. Seeds 2-2.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Western North America (United States and Mexico). |discussion=

Subspecies 3 (3 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Capsules closely prickly; bud prickles often branched. |[[Argemone pleiacantha subsp. pleiacantha|Argemone pleiacantha subsp. pleiacantha]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Capsules sparingly prickly; bud prickles simple. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Blades of proximal leaves lobed 4/5 distance to midrib, distal not clasping. |[[Argemone pleiacantha subsp. pinnatisecta|Argemone pleiacantha subsp. pinnatisecta]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Blades of proximal leaves lobed 1/2–2/3 distance to midrib, distal often clasping. |[[Argemone pleiacantha subsp. ambigua|Argemone pleiacantha subsp. ambigua]] |}

Capsules sparingly prickly.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer; fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Dry slopes and embankments, foothills |elevation=1000-1800 m |distribution=Ariz. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Argemone pleiacantha subsp. ambigua |authority=G. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Argemone pleiacantha subsp. pinnatisecta |accepted_authority=G. B. Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot.
